ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course, I learned a lot about the history of France from 1871 to the present.  More broadly, I developed an ability to analytically read and extract information from primary and secondary sources, construct a historical argument, and perform independent historical research.
French history from 1870 to modern day.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the greatest strengths of the course are Professor Merriman's lectures (he is extremely passionate about the subject, funny, and very engaging) and the readings/films he assigns.  Some of the books we read, in particular, including Germinal, A Life of Her Own, and Under Fire, were excellent and extremely enlightening.  In fact, I would venture to say they are worth reading even for people with little to no interest in the history of France.  The films, including Paths of Glory, the Battle of Algiers, and La Haine, are similarly worth anyone's time.
I think Professor Merriman did a great job of maintaining the community and environment of lecture over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course worked very well in its virtual format.  Lectures and sections both proceeded smoothly over Zoom.  I don't think there is any real room for improvement in this regard.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!  You will learn a lot about an interesting subject, and it is taught in an extremely fun manner.  As for the workload, it isn't too burdensome; however, if you take time to do all the readings, you will get so much out of them.
yes but only if you're interested in france beforehand. if not it will be very boring

Absolutely. Professor Merriman is a lively and engaging lecturer, and the course traces everything from the Paris Commune to Vichy France to immigration and the banlieues in contemporary France. The readings and documentaries were excellent and expectations for section were very fair.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had virtual sections over Zoom.
Live section, recorded and live lectures.
